In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

In Julia, you can write a function to clean column names as follows:

```julia
function clean_column(col::String)
    # Lowercase the string
    lc_col = lowercase(col)
    # Strip leading and trailing whitespaces
    trimmed_col = strip(lc_col)
    # Replace spaces and hyphens with underscores
    cleaned_col = replace(trimmed_col, r"\s|-" => "_")
    return cleaned_col
end
```

This function takes a `String` as input and returns the cleaned column name. It first lowers the case of the string, then strips any leading and trailing whitespace using `strip()`, which is a built-in Julia function that removes both leading and trailing whitespace from the string. Finally, it uses `replace()` to replace spaces and hyphens with underscores.

The regular expression `r"\s|-"` matches any whitespace character or hyphen. The replacement pattern `"_"` replaces each match with an underscore.

You can call this function on individual strings or use it to clean column names in a dataset, depending on your needs.
